subject: Add meson build
commitMessage:
Add meson build

This commit is to add meson build.
And later, we will remove Autotools and replace it with meson build.

In addition, fixed Layout::LedAction construct parameter error in test
file.

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I58c9a2c9de928db288e77ca2d6aa807d36e70144

Change has been successfully merged by Vishwanatha Subbanna
This commit also seems to fix few errors that are complained by meson, please update the commit msg to include every detail.

Since i have removed `xyz/` from fault-monitor, So my aim is to increase `meson build`.

I only found that the Layout::LedAction construct parameter error in the test file.

There is already a tool called 'sdbus++-gendir' that automatically generates all these pieces. Look at 'example/meson.build' in sdbusplus repository to understand how it is used.  That tool will let you eliminate all these tree of meson.build files under xyz/
Done
this is redundant ?
yes, removed
I dont know much about led-manager , but is this change related to this commit ?

Yeah.
The idea at the beginning was `xyz/` belongs to the fault-monitor process, so moved to the fault-monitor.
It has been restored.

Please restore this to wherever it was before.  Today, only fault monitor may be using it.. but tomorrow, it might be used by led manager also

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-host-ipmid is also maintaining at top
yes, restored :)
All this can be removed if we use the 'sdbus++-gendir' tool.
Ack

Need to also include minimum meson version that this build file can compile. As meson version in CI and yocto changes quite often , its always good to add this.

And also need a default build type flag as well , probably debugoptimized.
Done
Would be good if you give the required field as well, it would be easy for newbies to understand  better.
Ack
I see lot of json stuff, is nlohmann json dependency not needed ?
right, added.
Do you want to sort them in any way ?
Yes
Need a conditional check to see if tests option is enabled, before calling the subdir otherwise..you will end up compiling tests even when they are disabled
Done
the meson build files are triggered exactly in the order in which we call subdir(), so i would suggest to move this ahead of subdir(test)
Done
IMO meson options should be lower case. even it it not, lets maintain consistency across all meson options, that will look better.
i dont think we need it, removed.
here as well
Done
Do you have access to docker CI ?  I suggest running the same environment as the OpenBMC-CI and just drop support for cross compiling unit tests.

I think the original intention of adding meson is not to change the previous logic. 
Maybe I don't understand what u mean.
Sorry :)

> I think the original intention of adding meson is not to change the previous logic. 
> Maybe I don't understand what u mean.
> Sorry :)

The oe-sdk option has been a relic & here it was used to obtain dynamic linker flags from the sdk and pass it to meson. This was used when people use the x86 sdk(where we do a cross compile using x86-gcc) for compiling the unittests.

But with time, openbmc community is moving towards using docker based CI for unit testing, As the docker CI for a meson repo does a whole lot of things like(valigrind checks, running static analysers, running address sanitizer, running code coverage) which are not possible by an x86 sdk. couple of repos like entity manager & sdbusplus has already removed them.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/testing/local-ci-build.md

Its okay if you still wanna keep it, but just wanted to bring this point that, compiling unit tests using x86 sdk has become almost obsolete.

Thanks for ur suggestion :)
For me personally, use the x86 sdk is very convenient now.
In the future, I will definitely remove it.

@Vishwa, what do u think?
I would not add anything new because we are converting to meson. For now, lets only do what is needed to convert to meson. Later, we can come back add

> In the future, I will definitely remove it.

fair enough.
Ack
can directly use deps here ?
Done
Can we have all the dependencies at one place ? it looks easy & better that way.
Ack

This will break, without a meson wrap file under the subprojects directory. Are you planning on adding support for automatic dependency downloading when it is not found in the host system using meson wraps ? If not then this part would break the compilation as there is no nlohmann.wrap present in subprojects folder.

for reference on how to use meson subprojects, check this out https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/tree/master/subprojects

Thanks
Done
On a second thought ? Can this value break the compilation ? if yes , I think its better to add min & max value for class_verison that the repo can compile with.
I don't know. I would say lets use what has been used before. If need be in the future, we can then add it

> I don't know. I would say lets use what has been used before. If need be in the future, we can then add it

@George, then In my opinion, it is better to hard code this option/value in config.h rather than exposing it outside with meson_options.txt. Because when we expose some option via meson_option.txt, bbappends from other meta-layers can override this value to anything(because it does not have a min/max value) and can lead to a failure.

Got it, thanks :)
Done
This is also a dependency right ? can you move it up ?

Right.
Done.
this also should include nlohmann ? and this should be moved up

Yeah.
Done
Do you also wanna support meson wraps for sdbusplus,phosphor-dbus-interfaces, gtest & gmock ? Its okay if you want to do it as a part of another commit though.
Since these packages are required, I dont think these wraps are supported :)

> Since these packages are required, I dont think these wraps are supported :)

if sdbusplus is not found in sdk or in host, meson wraps will help us to download them at configure step and compile the code, so with that support - it will not break the compilation. 

In current moment, couple of repos like entity-manager, bmcweb e.t.c have support for sdbusplus, gtest , gmock wraps 

But its okay if you want to pick it up in another patch

> if sdbusplus is not found in sdk or in host, meson wraps will help us to download them at configure step and compile the code, so with that support - it will not break the compilation.

Right, Thanks for your succession. :)
Do we need to sync the version ID in meson wraps when the SDK updated?
If so, I think we can support these wraps in the future because I dont want to break the logic, Maybe @Vishwa agrees with me.
@Vishwa, what do u think?
My suggestion is to do anything else as part of another commit and use this commit to do only what is required to move to Meson.
Sure.

> Do we need to sync the version ID in meson wraps when the SDK updated?

No, we don't need to if we write the wraps in such a way that they point to HEAD of the repo.
For example: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/subprojects/sdbusplus.wrap

This should go in config.h right ? should be something like below. 

conf_data.set('CLASS_VERSION', 1)
Yeah, Thanks:)

This calls fault-monitor/meson.build file which uses fault_files variable.But by the time we call. fault_files is undefined.Please define fault_files before calling subdir()

fault-monitor/meson.build:1:0: ERROR: Unknown variable "fault_files".

A full log can be found at /home/jenkins-op/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/build/meson-logs/meson-log.txt
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/jenkins-op/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/unit-test.py", line 873, in configure
    check_call_cmd('meson', 'setup', '--reconfigure', 'build',
  File "/home/jenkins-op/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/unit-test.py", line 229, in check_call_cmd
    check_call(cmd)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/subprocess.py", line 364, in check_call
    raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd)
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '('meson', 'setup', '--reconfigure', 'build', '-Db_colorout=never', '-Dwerror=true', '-Dwarning_level=3', '--buildtype=debug', '-Dtests=enabled')' returned non-zero exit status 1.

Thanks very much :)
Done.

looks like we are failing to link the custom targets on a ppc machine only while creating the phosphor-fru-fault-monitor binray. I am not very sure of this but,

Can we make the custom targets to link..explicitly rather than implicitly, something like below and see if this error goes away:

sources = [
    'fru-fault-monitor.cpp',
    'monitor-main.cpp',
]
executable(
    'phosphor-fru-fault-monitor',
    sources,
    include_directories: ['../'],
    dependencies: deps,
    link_with : fault_files,	
    install: true,
    install_dir: get_option('bindir')
)
fault_generated_files ?
Done
wonder why it is not in the fault-monitor/meson.build ?

if we move this logic to fault-monitor/meson.build & change the input to meson.source_root()+'/xyz',the sdbusgen_prog tool seems to creates meson.source_root() directory hierarchy in the build directory & then placing the output hpp & cpp files there. So, this needs a code as to include the headers from the right location as well. not sure , if there is another way to do this.

@patrick,can you tell us ,how do we generate the hpp & cpp files inside builddir/xyz/.. even when the tool is run from a subdirectory ? or is the tool only to be used from the root meson.build file ?
this is also to be "disabled" by default right ?
No, it should be enabled.
not this.. My comment was on "oe-sdk"
Done

hmm.. why is this being put in here ?.. Is this the norm in all the repos ?
This is more of a openbmc/.bb/.bbappend construct. Why do we have it here ?
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/37661/6/meson.build#65
will this be cleaned as part of completing the build ?

No, it will generate the following file:

fault-monitor/xyz/openbmc_project/Led/Fru/Monitor/error.hpp
fault-monitor/xyz/openbmc_project/Led/Fru/Monitor/error.cpp
fault-monitor/xyz/openbmc_project/Led/Mapper/error.hpp
fault-monitor/xyz/openbmc_project/Led/Mapper/error.cpp

right.. I get it.. I'm asking if these files get cleaned after compilation . They were getting cleaned in auto_tools version.

CLEANFILES = ${BUILT_SOURCES}

No, We do not need to `clean files` in `meson.build`.

I asked @ManojKiran, and the reply I got was:
meson always does an out-off-tree build, it creates all these files inside a builddirectory

sure.. but that does not answer the question. The question is : what happens to the generated files ?. should they not be deleted at the end of compilation like how they are done when done using auto tools ?

Vishwa, meson by default genrates a "clean" target, so "ninja -C builddir clean" should clean all the built binaries & custom targets.

But fault_generated_files is not a custom  target as such, instead we are generating it from the sdbusgen_prog via a custom command, i dont think ninja can clean these files for us.

But unlike autotools ,meson generates all the build artifacts into a separate build folder rather than the source folder, so "ninja -C builddir clean" should be almost similar to "rm -rf builddir" right ?
Sounds reasonable. I was just looking to see the equivalent of "make clean" and I believe what you say is "ninja -C build clean" will do the thing. So, I am good. Thanks.
Also : where is the equivalent of _CFLAGS and _LDFLAGS that we had in auto tools version.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/37661/24/meson.build#52
I did not see this in some other repos. Is there anything that is demanding this to be explicitly specified ?

This is ManojKiran's suggestion 😊

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/37661/2/meson.build#1
okay .. @Manoj : May I know why this is needed ?

meson default build type is debug(which does not have any optimization at all) if nothing is specified, where as debugoptimized enables -O2 optimization during build time.

when this repo is pulled and compiled in yocto environment, it forces an "-O2" optimization for all the repos while compiling for bmc.

I idea behind explicitly mentioning the buildtype as debugoptimized would force the "repo specific docker CI" as well to do a similar build as yocto by enforcing an -O2. Its not a standard as such, but recent repos that are migrated to meson have been following this.
Thank you Manoj

See: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/37661/6/meson.build#65
Okay.. @Manoj : May I know why this is needed than always putting a dependency ?

By, having it this way, if nlohmann-json package is not present in the development machine/sdk, it will not break the compilation throwing an error , instead it fetches the nlohmann-json headers and then include them in the headers and proceeds for compilation.

This is a new feature in meson..by which we can automatically download the dependencies during the configure step if they are not found the machine.

Again, this is a new feature in meson & it does not harm us in anyway..but something nice to have.
Thanks Manoj.

what is replacing this here in meson ?
Requirement is that : by default, USE_JSON and LAMP_TEST needs to be disabled. We need to set EXTRA_OECONF in .bb file to define these variables and then they should be taken here.

> Requirement is that : by default, USE_JSON and LAMP_TEST needs to be disabled

Yes, when USE_JSON and LAMP_TEST are disabled, they will generate in config.h:
#undef LED_USE_JSON
#undef USE_LAMP_TEST
So, I think this is correct.

> We need to set EXTRA_OECONF in .bb file to define these variables and then they should be taken here.

nit: s/EXTRA_OECONF/EXTRA_OEMESON_append
No, we only added `EXTRA_OEMESON_append` to *.bbappend.

> Yes, when USE_JSON and LAMP_TEST are disabled, they will generate in config.h:
> #undef LED_USE_JSON
> #undef USE_LAMP_TEST

Sorry, I am not following. Are you saying when you have ".disabled()", they are considered enabled and hence USE_JSON will be true ?

> Sorry, I am not following. Are you saying when you have ".disabled()", they are considered enabled and hence USE_JSON will be true ?

No.
when we have `.disabled()` for `LED_USE_JSON`(this is by default), it will generate in config.h:
#undef LED_USE_JSON

But, we have `.enabled()` for `LED_USE_JSON`(EXTRA_OEMESON_append = 'Duse-json=enabled'),  it will generate in config.h:
#define LED_USE_JSON

does make sense?
could you add comments here ( at line: 86 ) since this change is being done  ? What issue is it going to resolve ?

a boolean telling whether Meson adds the current source and build directories to the include path, defaults to true.

refer to: https://mesonbuild.com/Reference-manual.html#include_directories

There is a little danger here...

You've got a variable in (root)/meson.build named 'sources' and a variable here named 'sources'.  You are, in effect, overwriting the 'sources' found in the parent directory at the point that you have the 'subdir(fault-monitor)' call.  If someone moves that line around you can end up with very different behavior.

I suggest using another name (fault_monitor_sources maybe).
